docstr: `ASIN` — Arcsine function ### Description `ASIN(X)` computes the arcsine of its `X` (inverse of `SIN(X)`). ### Syntax `RESULT = ASIN(X)` ### Arguments and a magnitude that is less than or equal to one - or be `COMPLEX`. ### Return value The return value is of the same type and kind as `X`. The real part of the result is in radians and lies in the range -\pi/2 \leq \Re \asin(x) \leq \pi/2. ### Example ``` program test_asin   real(8) :: x = 0.866_8   x = asin(x) end program test_asin ``` ### Specific names | Name | Argument | Return type | Standard | `ASIN(X)` | `REAL(4) X` | `REAL(4)` | Fortran 77 and later | `DASIN(X)` | `REAL(8) X` | `REAL(8)` | Fortran 77 and later ### Standard Fortran 77 and later, for a complex argument Fortran 2008 or later ### Class Elemental function ### See also Inverse function: SIN
